newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli police clash with ultra-Orthodox protesters.
newsitem.headline: Israeli police clash with ultra-Orthodox protesters.

text.p: Two Israeli policemen were injured on Saturday in clashes with ultra-Orthodox Jews trying to close a Jerusalem street that Israel's High Court said should remain open to traffic on the sabbath, a police spokesman said.
Witnesses said police held back thousands of religious Jews in traditional black garb who tried to block traffic on Bar Ilan street, a main Jerusalem thoroughfare.
"Two policemen were injured and seven people have been arrested so far, some of them for stone throwing," the spokesman said.
Police increased their presence on the street on Saturday after the High Court ruling last Sunday to keep Bar Ilan open on the sabbath.
The ruling ended an unofficial eight-month truce along the street and drew threats from members of the ultra-Orthodox community to renew weekly Saturday protests against the road being open.
The ruling cancelled last year's decision by Transportation Minister Yitzhak Levy, an Orthodox Jew, to close Bar-Ilan street during prayer times on the sabbath and Jewish holidays.
Ultra-Orthodox Jews had suspended their protests pending the court's decision on left-wing appeals against Levy's edict.
Jewish ritual law forbids the operation of machinery, including automobiles, on the sabbath which runs from Friday night to Saturday night.
